content:
Yes, VO2max can also be estimated from a steady-state run using various formulas. One commonly used formula is the Cooper test, which estimates VO2max based on the distance covered during a 12-minute run. The Cooper test is a simple field test that can be performed on a track or any flat surface.

The formula for estimating VO2max based on the Cooper test is as follows:

VO2max (ml/kg/min)=22.351×(distance (km)12 minutes)−3.28\text{VO2max (ml/kg/min)} = 22.351 \times \left( \frac{\text{distance (km)}}{12 \text{ minutes}} \right) - 3.28VO2max (ml/kg/min)=22.351×(12 minutesdistance (km)​)−3.28Where:

* VO2max is the maximal oxygen uptake in milliliters per kilogram per minute (ml/kg/min).
* distance (km) is the total distance covered during the 12-minute run, measured in kilometers.

If you have data from a steady-state run, such as the total distance covered during a 12-minute run, you can use this formula to estimate your VO2max. Please provide the total distance covered (in kilometers) during the 12-minute run, and I can calculate your estimated VO2max for you.

Keep in mind that these formulas provide an estimation of VO2max and may not be as accurate as laboratory-based tests. However, they can still be useful for tracking changes in aerobic fitness over time.
